column17: Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble is like a broken tooth, and a foot out of joint.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As he that taketh away a garment in cold weather, and as vinegar upon nitre, so is he that singeth songs to an heavy heart.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: If thine enemy be hungry, give him bread to eat; and if he be thirsty, give him water to drink:

column8: The Proverbs
column17: For thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head, and the Lord shall reward thee.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The north wind driveth away rain: so doth an angry countenance a backbiting tongue.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: It is better to dwell in the corner of the housetop, than with a brawling woman and in a wide house.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As cold waters to a thirsty soul, so is good news from a far country.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A righteous man falling down before the wicked is as a troubled fountain, and a corrupt spring.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: It is not good to eat much honey: so for men to search their own glory is not glory.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that hath no rule over his own spirit is like a city that is broken down, and without walls.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As snow in summer, and as rain in harvest, so honour is not seemly for a fool.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As the bird by wandering, as the swallow by flying, so the curse causeless shall not come.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the ass, and a rod for the fool's back.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Answer not a fool according to his folly, lest thou also be like unto him.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he be wise in his own conceit.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that sendeth a message by the hand of a fool cutteth off the feet, and drinketh damage.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The legs of the lame are not equal: so is a parable in the mouth of fools.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As he that bindeth a stone in a sling, so is he that giveth honour to a fool.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As a thorn goeth up into the hand of a drunkard, so is a parable in the mouth of fools.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The great God that formed all things both rewardeth the fool, and rewardeth transgressors.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As a dog returneth to his vomit, so a fool returneth to his folly.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Seest thou a man wise in his own conceit? there is more hope of a fool than of him.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The slothful man saith, There is a lion in the way; a lion is in the streets.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As the door turneth upon his hinges, so doth the slothful upon his bed.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The slothful hideth his hand in his bosom; it grieveth him to bring it again to his mouth.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The sluggard is wiser in his own conceit than seven men that can render a reason.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that passeth by, and meddleth with strife belonging not to him, is like one that taketh a dog by the ears.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As a mad man who casteth firebrands, arrows, and death,

column8: The Proverbs
column17: So is the man that deceiveth his neighbour, and saith, Am not I in sport?

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Where no wood is, there the fire goeth out: so where there is no talebearer, the strife ceaseth.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As coals are to burning coals, and wood to fire; so is a contentious man to kindle strife.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The words of a talebearer are as wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Burning lips and a wicked heart are like a potsherd covered with silver dross.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that hateth dissembleth with his lips, and layeth up deceit within him;

column8: The Proverbs
column17: When he speaketh fair, believe him not: for there are seven abominations in his heart.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Whose hatred is covered by deceit, his wickedness shall be shewed before the whole congregation.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Whoso diggeth a pit shall fall therein: and he that rolleth a stone, it will return upon him.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A lying tongue hateth those that are afflicted by it; and a flattering mouth worketh ruin.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Boast not thyself of to morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Let another man praise thee, and not thine own mouth; a stranger, and not thine own lips.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A stone is heavy, and the sand weighty; but a fool's wrath is heavier than them both.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Wrath is cruel, and anger is outrageous; but who is able to stand before envy?

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Open rebuke is better than secret love.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Faithful are the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The full soul loatheth an honeycomb; but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As a bird that wandereth from her nest, so is a man that wandereth from his place.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart: so doth the sweetness of a man's friend by hearty counsel.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Thine own friend, and thy father's friend, forsake not; neither go into thy brother's house in the day of thy calamity: for better is a neighbour that is near than a brother far off.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, that I may answer him that reproacheth me.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A prudent man foreseeth the evil, and hideth himself; but the simple pass on, and are punished.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Take his garment that is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that blesseth his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A continual dropping in a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Whosoever hideth her hideth the wind, and the ointment of his right hand, which bewrayeth itself.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Whoso keepeth the fig tree shall eat the fruit thereof: so he that waiteth on his master shall be honoured.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As in water face answereth to face, so the heart of man to man.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Hell and destruction are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As the fining pot for silver, and the furnace for gold; so is a man to his praise.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Though thou shouldest bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, yet will not his foolishness depart from him.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Be thou diligent to know the state of thy flocks, and look well to thy herds.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: For riches are not for ever: and doth the crown endure to every generation?

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The hay appeareth, and the tender grass sheweth itself, and herbs of the mountains are gathered.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The lambs are for thy clothing, and the goats are the price of the field.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: And thou shalt have goats' milk enough for thy food, for the food of thy household, and for the maintenance for thy maidens.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The wicked flee when no man pursueth: but the righteous are bold as a lion.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: For the transgression of a land many are the princes thereof: but by a man of understanding and knowledge the state thereof shall be prolonged.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A poor man that oppresseth the poor is like a sweeping rain which leaveth no food.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: They that forsake the law praise the wicked: but such as keep the law contend with them.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Evil men understand not judgment: but they that seek the Lord understand all things.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Better is the poor that walketh in his uprightness, than he that is perverse in his ways, though he be rich.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Whoso keepeth the law is a wise son: but he that is a companion of riotous men shameth his father.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that by usury and unjust gain increaseth his substance, he shall gather it for him that will pity the poor.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that turneth away his ear from hearing the law, even his prayer shall be abomination.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Whoso causeth the righteous to go astray in an evil way, he shall fall himself into his own pit: but the upright shall have good things in possession.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The rich man is wise in his own conceit; but the poor that hath understanding searcheth him out.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: When righteous men do rejoice, there is great glory: but when the wicked rise, a man is hidden.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that covereth his sins shall not prosper: but whoso confesseth and forsaketh them shall have mercy.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Happy is the man that feareth alway: but he that hardeneth his heart shall fall into mischief.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: As a roaring lion, and a ranging bear; so is a wicked ruler over the poor people.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The prince that wanteth understanding is also a great oppressor: but he that hateth covetousness shall prolong his days.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A man that doeth violence to the blood of any person shall flee to the pit; let no man stay him.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Whoso walketh uprightly shall be saved: but he that is perverse in his ways shall fall at once.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that tilleth his land shall have plenty of bread: but he that followeth after vain persons shall have poverty enough.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A faithful man shall abound with blessings: but he that maketh haste to be rich shall not be innocent.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: To have respect of persons is not good: for for a piece of bread that man will transgress.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that hasteth to be rich hath an evil eye, and considereth not that poverty shall come upon him.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that rebuketh a man afterwards shall find more favour than he that flattereth with the tongue.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Whoso robbeth his father or his mother, and saith, It is no transgression; the same is the companion of a destroyer.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that is of a proud heart stirreth up strife: but he that putteth his trust in the Lord shall be made fat.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that trusteth in his own heart is a fool: but whoso walketh wisely, he shall be delivered.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that giveth unto the poor shall not lack: but he that hideth his eyes shall have many a curse.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: When the wicked rise, men hide themselves: but when they perish, the righteous increase.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He, that being often reproved hardeneth his neck, shall suddenly be destroyed, and that without remedy.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: When the righteous are in authority, the people rejoice: but when the wicked beareth rule, the people mourn.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Whoso loveth wisdom rejoiceth his father: but he that keepeth company with harlots spendeth his substance.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The king by judgment establisheth the land: but he that receiveth gifts overthroweth it.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A man that flattereth his neighbour spreadeth a net for his feet.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: In the transgression of an evil man there is a snare: but the righteous doth sing and rejoice.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The righteous considereth the cause of the poor: but the wicked regardeth not to know it.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Scornful men bring a city into a snare: but wise men turn away wrath.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: If a wise man contendeth with a foolish man, whether he rage or laugh, there is no rest.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The bloodthirsty hate the upright: but the just seek his soul.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A fool uttereth all his mind: but a wise man keepeth it in till afterwards.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: If a ruler hearken to lies, all his servants are wicked.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The poor and the deceitful man meet together: the Lord lighteneth both their eyes.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The king that faithfully judgeth the poor, his throne shall be established for ever.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The rod and reproof give wisdom: but a child left to himself bringeth his mother to shame.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: When the wicked are multiplied, transgression increaseth: but the righteous shall see their fall.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Correct thy son, and he shall give thee rest; yea, he shall give delight unto thy soul.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Where there is no vision, the people perish: but he that keepeth the law, happy is he.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A servant will not be corrected by words: for though he understand he will not answer.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Seest thou a man that is hasty in his words? there is more hope of a fool than of him.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: He that delicately bringeth up his servant from a child shall have him become his son at the length.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: An angry man stirreth up strife, and a furious man aboundeth in transgression.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A man's pride shall bring him low: but honour shall uphold the humble in spirit.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Whoso is partner with a thief hateth his own soul: he heareth cursing, and bewrayeth it not.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The fear of man bringeth a snare: but whoso putteth his trust in the Lord shall be safe.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Many seek the ruler's favour; but every man's judgment cometh from the Lord.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: An unjust man is an abomination to the just: and he that is upright in the way is abomination to the wicked.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The words of Agur the son of Jakeh, even the prophecy: the man spake unto Ithiel, even unto Ithiel and Ucal,

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Surely I am more brutish than any man, and have not the understanding of a man.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: I neither learned wisdom, nor have the knowledge of the holy.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Who hath ascended up into heaven, or descended? who hath gathered the wind in his fists? who hath bound the waters in a garment? who hath established all the ends of the earth? what is his name, and what is his son's name, if thou canst tell?

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Every word of God is pure: he is a shield unto them that put their trust in him.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Add thou not unto his words, lest he reprove thee, and thou be found a liar.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Two things have I required of thee; deny me them not before I die:

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Remove far from me vanity and lies: give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with food convenient for me:

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Lest I be full, and deny thee, and say, Who is the Lord? or lest I be poor, and steal, and take the name of my God in vain.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Accuse not a servant unto his master, lest he curse thee, and thou be found guilty.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: There is a generation that curseth their father, and doth not bless their mother.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: There is a generation that are pure in their own eyes, and yet is not washed from their filthiness.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: There is a generation, O how lofty are their eyes! and their eyelids are lifted up.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: There is a generation, whose teeth are as swords, and their jaw teeth as knives, to devour the poor from off the earth, and the needy from among men.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The horseleach hath two daughters, crying, Give, give. There are three things that are never satisfied, yea, four things say not, It is enough:

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The grave; and the barren womb; the earth that is not filled with water; and the fire that saith not, It is enough.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The eye that mocketh at his father, and despiseth to obey his mother, the ravens of the valley shall pick it out, and the young eagles shall eat it.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: There be three things which are too wonderful for me, yea, four which I know not:

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The way of an eagle in the air; the way of a serpent upon a rock; the way of a ship in the midst of the sea; and the way of a man with a maid.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Such is the way of an adulterous woman; she eateth, and wipeth her mouth, and saith, I have done no wickedness.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: For three things the earth is disquieted, and for four which it cannot bear:

column8: The Proverbs
column17: For a servant when he reigneth; and a fool when he is filled with meat;

column8: The Proverbs
column17: For an odious woman when she is married; and an handmaid that is heir to her mistress.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: There be four things which are little upon the earth, but they are exceeding wise:

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The ants are a people not strong, yet they prepare their meat in the summer;

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The conies are but a feeble folk, yet make they their houses in the rocks;

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The locusts have no king, yet go they forth all of them by bands;

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The spider taketh hold with her hands, and is in kings' palaces.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: There be three things which go well, yea, four are comely in going:

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A lion which is strongest among beasts, and turneth not away for any;

column8: The Proverbs
column17: A greyhound; an he goat also; and a king, against whom there is no rising up.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: If thou hast done foolishly in lifting up thyself, or if thou hast thought evil, lay thine hand upon thy mouth.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Surely the churning of milk bringeth forth butter, and the wringing of the nose bringeth forth blood: so the forcing of wrath bringeth forth strife.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The words of king Lemuel, the prophecy that his mother taught him.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: What, my son? and what, the son of my womb? and what, the son of my vows?

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Give not thy strength unto women, nor thy ways to that which destroyeth kings.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine; nor for princes strong drink:

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Lest they drink, and forget the law, and pervert the judgment of any of the afflicted.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Give strong drink unto him that is ready to perish, and wine unto those that be of heavy hearts.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Let him drink, and forget his poverty, and remember his misery no more.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Open thy mouth for the dumb in the cause of all such as are appointed to destruction.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Open thy mouth, judge righteously, and plead the cause of the poor and needy.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Who can find a virtuous woman? for her price is far above rubies.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: The heart of her husband doth safely trust in her, so that he shall have no need of spoil.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She will do him good and not evil all the days of her life.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She seeketh wool, and flax, and worketh willingly with her hands.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She is like the merchants' ships; she bringeth her food from afar.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She riseth also while it is yet night, and giveth meat to her household, and a portion to her maidens.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She considereth a field, and buyeth it: with the fruit of her hands she planteth a vineyard.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She girdeth her loins with strength, and strengtheneth her arms.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She perceiveth that her merchandise is good: her candle goeth not out by night.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She layeth her hands to the spindle, and her hands hold the distaff.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She stretcheth out her hand to the poor; yea, she reacheth forth her hands to the needy.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She is not afraid of the snow for her household: for all her household are clothed with scarlet.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She maketh herself coverings of tapestry; her clothing is silk and purple.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Her husband is known in the gates, when he sitteth among the elders of the land.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She maketh fine linen, and selleth it; and delivereth girdles unto the merchant.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Strength and honour are her clothing; and she shall rejoice in time to come.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She openeth her mouth with wisdom; and in her tongue is the law of kindness.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: She looketh well to the ways of her household, and eateth not the bread of idleness.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Her children arise up, and call her blessed; her husband also, and he praiseth her.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Many daughters have done virtuously, but thou excellest them all.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Favour is deceitful, and beauty is vain: but a woman that feareth the Lord, she shall be praised.

column8: The Proverbs
column17: Give her of the fruit of her hands; and let her own works praise her in the gates.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Vanity of vanities, saith the Preacher, vanity of vanities; all is vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: What profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: One generation passeth away, and another generation cometh: but the earth abideth for ever.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The sun also ariseth, and the sun goeth down, and hasteth to his place where he arose.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The wind goeth toward the south, and turneth about unto the north; it whirleth about continually, and the wind returneth again according to his circuits.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: All the rivers run into the sea; yet the sea is not full; unto the place from whence the rivers come, thither they return again.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: All things are full of labour; man cannot utter it: the eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The thing that hath been, it is that which shall be; and that which is done is that which shall be done: and there is no new thing under the sun.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Is there any thing whereof it may be said, See, this is new? it hath been already of old time, which was before us.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: There is no remembrance of former things; neither shall there be any remembrance of things that are to come with those that shall come after.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I the Preacher was king over Israel in Jerusalem.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And I gave my heart to seek and search out by wisdom concerning all things that are done under heaven: this sore travail hath God given to the sons of man to be exercised therewith.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I have seen all the works that are done under the sun; and, behold, all is vanity and vexation of spirit.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: That which is crooked cannot be made straight: and that which is wanting cannot be numbered.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I communed with mine own heart, saying, Lo, I am come to great estate, and have gotten more wisdom than all they that have been before me in Jerusalem: yea, my heart had great experience of wisdom and knowledge.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And I gave my heart to know wisdom, and to know madness and folly: I perceived that this also is vexation of spirit.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For in much wisdom is much grief: and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I said in mine heart, Go to now, I will prove thee with mirth, therefore enjoy pleasure: and, behold, this also is vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I said of laughter, It is mad: and of mirth, What doeth it?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I sought in mine heart to give myself unto wine, yet acquainting mine heart with wisdom; and to lay hold on folly, till I might see what was that good for the sons of men, which they should do under the heaven all the days of their life.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I made me great works; I builded me houses; I planted me vineyards:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I made me gardens and orchards, and I planted trees in them of all kind of fruits:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I made me pools of water, to water therewith the wood that bringeth forth trees:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I got me servants and maidens, and had servants born in my house; also I had great possessions of great and small cattle above all that were in Jerusalem before me:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I gathered me also silver and gold, and the peculiar treasure of kings and of the provinces: I gat me men singers and women singers, and the delights of the sons of men, as musical instruments, and that of all sorts.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: So I was great, and increased more than all that were before me in Jerusalem: also my wisdom remained with me.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And whatsoever mine eyes desired I kept not from them, I withheld not my heart from any joy; for my heart rejoiced in all my labour: and this was my portion of all my labour.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Then I looked on all the works that my hands had wrought, and on the labour that I had laboured to do: and, behold, all was vanity and vexation of spirit, and there was no profit under the sun.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And I turned myself to behold wisdom, and madness, and folly: for what can the man do that cometh after the king? even that which hath been already done.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Then I saw that wisdom excelleth folly, as far as light excelleth darkness.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The wise man's eyes are in his head; but the fool walketh in darkness: and I myself perceived also that one event happeneth to them all.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Then said I in my heart, As it happeneth to the fool, so it happeneth even to me; and why was I then more wise? Then I said in my heart, that this also is vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For there is no remembrance of the wise more than of the fool for ever; seeing that which now is in the days to come shall all be forgotten. And how dieth the wise man? as the fool.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Therefore I hated life; because the work that is wrought under the sun is grievous unto me: for all is vanity and vexation of spirit.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Yea, I hated all my labour which I had taken under the sun: because I should leave it unto the man that shall be after me.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And who knoweth whether he shall be a wise man or a fool? yet shall he have rule over all my labour wherein I have laboured, and wherein I have shewed myself wise under the sun. This is also vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Therefore I went about to cause my heart to despair of all the labour which I took under the sun.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For there is a man whose labour is in wisdom, and in knowledge, and in equity; yet to a man that hath not laboured therein shall he leave it for his portion. This also is vanity and a great evil.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For what hath man of all his labour, and of the vexation of his heart, wherein he hath laboured under the sun?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For all his days are sorrows, and his travail grief; yea, his heart taketh not rest in the night. This is also vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: There is nothing better for a man, than that he should eat and drink, and that he should make his soul enjoy good in his labour. This also I saw, that it was from the hand of God.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For who can eat, or who else can hasten hereunto, more than I?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For God giveth to a man that is good in his sight wisdom, and knowledge, and joy: but to the sinner he giveth travail, to gather and to heap up, that he may give to him that is good before God. This also is vanity and vexation of spirit.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted;

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A time to kill, and a time to heal; a time to break down, and a time to build up;

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A time to weep, and a time to laugh; a time to mourn, and a time to dance;

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A time to cast away stones, and a time to gather stones together; a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing;

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A time to get, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and a time to cast away;

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A time to rend, and a time to sew; a time to keep silence, and a time to speak;

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A time to love, and a time to hate; a time of war, and a time of peace.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: What profit hath he that worketh in that wherein he laboureth?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I have seen the travail, which God hath given to the sons of men to be exercised in it.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: He hath made every thing beautiful in his time: also he hath set the world in their heart, so that no man can find out the work that God maketh from the beginning to the end.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I know that there is no good in them, but for a man to rejoice, and to do good in his life.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And also that every man should eat and drink, and enjoy the good of all his labour, it is the gift of God.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I know that, whatsoever God doeth, it shall be for ever: nothing can be put to it, nor any thing taken from it: and God doeth it, that men should fear before him.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: That which hath been is now; and that which is to be hath already been; and God requireth that which is past.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And moreover I saw under the sun the place of judgment, that wickedness was there; and the place of righteousness, that iniquity was there.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I said in mine heart, God shall judge the righteous and the wicked: for there is a time there for every purpose and for every work.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I said in mine heart concerning the estate of the sons of men, that God might manifest them, and that they might see that they themselves are beasts.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For that which befalleth the sons of men befalleth beasts; even one thing befalleth them: as the one dieth, so dieth the other; yea, they have all one breath; so that a man hath no preeminence above a beast: for all is vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: All go unto one place; all are of the dust, and all turn to dust again.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Who knoweth the spirit of man that goeth upward, and the spirit of the beast that goeth downward to the earth?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Wherefore I perceive that there is nothing better, than that a man should rejoice in his own works; for that is his portion: for who shall bring him to see what shall be after him?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: So I returned, and considered all the oppressions that are done under the sun: and behold the tears of such as were oppressed, and they had no comforter; and on the side of their oppressors there was power; but they had no comforter.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Wherefore I praised the dead which are already dead more than the living which are yet alive.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Yea, better is he than both they, which hath not yet been, who hath not seen the evil work that is done under the sun.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Again, I considered all travail, and every right work, that for this a man is envied of his neighbour. This is also vanity and vexation of spirit.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The fool foldeth his hands together, and eateth his own flesh.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Better is an handful with quietness, than both the hands full with travail and vexation of spirit.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Then I returned, and I saw vanity under the sun.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: There is one alone, and there is not a second; yea, he hath neither child nor brother: yet is there no end of all his labour; neither is his eye satisfied with riches; neither saith he, For whom do I labour, and bereave my soul of good? This is also vanity, yea, it is a sore travail.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Two are better than one; because they have a good reward for their labour.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For if they fall, the one will lift up his fellow: but woe to him that is alone when he falleth; for he hath not another to help him up.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Again, if two lie together, then they have heat: but how can one be warm alone?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And if one prevail against him, two shall withstand him; and a threefold cord is not quickly broken.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Better is a poor and a wise child than an old and foolish king, who will no more be admonished.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For out of prison he cometh to reign; whereas also he that is born in his kingdom becometh poor.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I considered all the living which walk under the sun, with the second child that shall stand up in his stead.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: There is no end of all the people, even of all that have been before them: they also that come after shall not rejoice in him. Surely this also is vanity and vexation of spirit.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Keep thy foot when thou goest to the house of God, and be more ready to hear, than to give the sacrifice of fools: for they consider not that they do evil.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Be not rash with thy mouth, and let not thine heart be hasty to utter any thing before God: for God is in heaven, and thou upon earth: therefore let thy words be few.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For a dream cometh through the multitude of business; and a fool's voice is known by multitude of words.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: When thou vowest a vow unto God, defer not to pay it; for he hath no pleasure in fools: pay that which thou hast vowed.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Better is it that thou shouldest not vow, than that thou shouldest vow and not pay.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Suffer not thy mouth to cause thy flesh to sin; neither say thou before the angel, that it was an error: wherefore should God be angry at thy voice, and destroy the work of thine hands?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For in the multitude of dreams and many words there are also divers vanities: but fear thou God.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: If thou seest the oppression of the poor, and violent perverting of judgment and justice in a province, marvel not at the matter: for he that is higher than the highest regardeth; and there be higher than they.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Moreover the profit of the earth is for all: the king himself is served by the field.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: He that loveth silver shall not be satisfied with silver; nor he that loveth abundance with increase: this is also vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: When goods increase, they are increased that eat them: and what good is there to the owners thereof, saving the beholding of them with their eyes?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The sleep of a labouring man is sweet, whether he eat little or much: but the abundance of the rich will not suffer him to sleep.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: There is a sore evil which I have seen under the sun, namely, riches kept for the owners thereof to their hurt.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: But those riches perish by evil travail: and he begetteth a son, and there is nothing in his hand.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: As he came forth of his mother's womb, naked shall he return to go as he came, and shall take nothing of his labour, which he may carry away in his hand.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And this also is a sore evil, that in all points as he came, so shall he go: and what profit hath he that hath laboured for the wind?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: All his days also he eateth in darkness, and he hath much sorrow and wrath with his sickness.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Behold that which I have seen: it is good and comely for one to eat and to drink, and to enjoy the good of all his labour that he taketh under the sun all the days of his life, which God giveth him: for it is his portion.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Every man also to whom God hath given riches and wealth, and hath given him power to eat thereof, and to take his portion, and to rejoice in his labour; this is the gift of God.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For he shall not much remember the days of his life; because God answereth him in the joy of his heart.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, and it is common among men:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A man to whom God hath given riches, wealth, and honour, so that he wanteth nothing for his soul of all that he desireth, yet God giveth him not power to eat thereof, but a stranger eateth it: this is vanity, and it is an evil disease.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: If a man beget an hundred children, and live many years, so that the days of his years be many, and his soul be not filled with good, and also that he have no burial; I say, that an untimely birth is better than he.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For he cometh in with vanity, and departeth in darkness, and his name shall be covered with darkness.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Moreover he hath not seen the sun, nor known any thing: this hath more rest than the other.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Yea, though he live a thousand years twice told, yet hath he seen no good: do not all go to one place?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: All the labour of man is for his mouth, and yet the appetite is not filled.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For what hath the wise more than the fool? what hath the poor, that knoweth to walk before the living?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the desire: this is also vanity and vexation of spirit.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: That which hath been is named already, and it is known that it is man: neither may he contend with him that is mightier than he.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Seeing there be many things that increase vanity, what is man the better?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For who knoweth what is good for man in this life, all the days of his vain life which he spendeth as a shadow? for who can tell a man what shall be after him under the sun?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A good name is better than precious ointment; and the day of death than the day of one's birth.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: It is better to go to the house of mourning, than to go to the house of feasting: for that is the end of all men; and the living will lay it to his heart.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Sorrow is better than laughter: for by the sadness of the countenance the heart is made better.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning; but the heart of fools is in the house of mirth.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: It is better to hear the rebuke of the wise, than for a man to hear the song of fools.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For as the crackling of thorns under a pot, so is the laughter of the fool: this also is vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Surely oppression maketh a wise man mad; and a gift destroyeth the heart.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Better is the end of a thing than the beginning thereof: and the patient in spirit is better than the proud in spirit.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Be not hasty in thy spirit to be angry: for anger resteth in the bosom of fools.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Say not thou, What is the cause that the former days were better than these? for thou dost not inquire wisely concerning this.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Wisdom is good with an inheritance: and by it there is profit to them that see the sun.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For wisdom is a defence, and money is a defence: but the excellency of knowledge is, that wisdom giveth life to them that have it.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Consider the work of God: for who can make that straight, which he hath made crooked?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: In the day of prosperity be joyful, but in the day of adversity consider: God also hath set the one over against the other, to the end that man should find nothing after him.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: All things have I seen in the days of my vanity: there is a just man that perisheth in his righteousness, and there is a wicked man that prolongeth his life in his wickedness.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Be not righteous over much; neither make thyself over wise: why shouldest thou destroy thyself?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Be not over much wicked, neither be thou foolish: why shouldest thou die before thy time?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: It is good that thou shouldest take hold of this; yea, also from this withdraw not thine hand: for he that feareth God shall come forth of them all.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Wisdom strengtheneth the wise more than ten mighty men which are in the city.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For there is not a just man upon earth, that doeth good, and sinneth not.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Also take no heed unto all words that are spoken; lest thou hear thy servant curse thee:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For oftentimes also thine own heart knoweth that thou thyself likewise hast cursed others.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: All this have I proved by wisdom: I said, I will be wise; but it was far from me.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: That which is far off, and exceeding deep, who can find it out?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I applied mine heart to know, and to search, and to seek out wisdom, and the reason of things, and to know the wickedness of folly, even of foolishness and madness:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And I find more bitter than death the woman, whose heart is snares and nets, and her hands as bands: whoso pleaseth God shall escape from her; but the sinner shall be taken by her.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Behold, this have I found, saith the preacher, counting one by one, to find out the account:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Which yet my soul seeketh, but I find not: one man among a thousand have I found; but a woman among all those have I not found.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Lo, this only have I found, that God hath made man upright; but they have sought out many inventions.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Who is as the wise man? and who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? a man's wisdom maketh his face to shine, and the boldness of his face shall be changed.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I counsel thee to keep the king's commandment, and that in regard of the oath of God.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Be not hasty to go out of his sight: stand not in an evil thing; for he doeth whatsoever pleaseth him.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Where the word of a king is, there is power: and who may say unto him, What doest thou?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Whoso keepeth the commandment shall feel no evil thing: and a wise man's heart discerneth both time and judgment.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Because to every purpose there is time and judgment, therefore the misery of man is great upon him.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For he knoweth not that which shall be: for who can tell him when it shall be?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: There is no man that hath power over the spirit to retain the spirit; neither hath he power in the day of death: and there is no discharge in that war; neither shall wickedness deliver those that are given to it.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: All this have I seen, and applied my heart unto every work that is done under the sun: there is a time wherein one man ruleth over another to his own hurt.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And so I saw the wicked buried, who had come and gone from the place of the holy, and they were forgotten in the city where they had so done: this is also vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Because sentence against an evil work is not executed speedily, therefore the heart of the sons of men is fully set in them to do evil.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Though a sinner do evil an hundred times, and his days be prolonged, yet surely I know that it shall be well with them that fear God, which fear before him:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: But it shall not be well with the wicked, neither shall he prolong his days, which are as a shadow; because he feareth not before God.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: There is a vanity which is done upon the earth; that there be just men, unto whom it happeneth according to the work of the wicked; again, there be wicked men, to whom it happeneth according to the work of the righteous: I said that this also is vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Then I commended mirth, because a man hath no better thing under the sun, than to eat, and to drink, and to be merry: for that shall abide with him of his labour the days of his life, which God giveth him under the sun.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: When I applied mine heart to know wisdom, and to see the business that is done upon the earth: (for also there is that neither day nor night seeth sleep with his eyes:)

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Then I beheld all the work of God, that a man cannot find out the work that is done under the sun: because though a man labour to seek it out, yet he shall not find it; yea further; though a wise man think to know it, yet shall he not be able to find it.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For all this I considered in my heart even to declare all this, that the righteous, and the wise, and their works, are in the hand of God: no man knoweth either love or hatred by all that is before them.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: All things come alike to all: there is one event to the righteous, and to the wicked; to the good and to the clean, and to the unclean; to him that sacrificeth, and to him that sacrificeth not: as is the good, so is the sinner; and he that sweareth, as he that feareth an oath.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: This is an evil among all things that are done under the sun, that there is one event unto all: yea, also the heart of the sons of men is full of evil, and madness is in their heart while they live, and after that they go to the dead.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For to him that is joined to all the living there is hope: for a living dog is better than a dead lion.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For the living know that they shall die: but the dead know not any thing, neither have they any more a reward; for the memory of them is forgotten.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Also their love, and their hatred, and their envy, is now perished; neither have they any more a portion for ever in any thing that is done under the sun.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Go thy way, eat thy bread with joy, and drink thy wine with a merry heart; for God now accepteth thy works.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Let thy garments be always white; and let thy head lack no ointment.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Live joyfully with the wife whom thou lovest all the days of the life of thy vanity, which he hath given thee under the sun, all the days of thy vanity: for that is thy portion in this life, and in thy labour which thou takest under the sun.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with thy might; for there is no work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor wisdom, in the grave, whither thou goest.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I returned, and saw under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favour to men of skill; but time and chance happeneth to them all.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For man also knoweth not his time: as the fishes that are taken in an evil net, and as the birds that are caught in the snare; so are the sons of men snared in an evil time, when it falleth suddenly upon them.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: This wisdom have I seen also under the sun, and it seemed great unto me:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: There was a little city, and few men within it; and there came a great king against it, and besieged it, and built great bulwarks against it:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Now there was found in it a poor wise man, and he by his wisdom delivered the city; yet no man remembered that same poor man.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Then said I, Wisdom is better than strength: nevertheless the poor man's wisdom is despised, and his words are not heard.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The words of wise men are heard in quiet more than the cry of him that ruleth among fools.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Wisdom is better than weapons of war: but one sinner destroyeth much good.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Dead flies cause the ointment of the apothecary to send forth a stinking savour: so doth a little folly him that is in reputation for wisdom and honour.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A wise man's heart is at his right hand; but a fool's heart at his left.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Yea also, when he that is a fool walketh by the way, his wisdom faileth him, and he saith to every one that he is a fool.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: If the spirit of the ruler rise up against thee, leave not thy place; for yielding pacifieth great offences.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, as an error which proceedeth from the ruler:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Folly is set in great dignity, and the rich sit in low place.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: I have seen servants upon horses, and princes walking as servants upon the earth.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: He that diggeth a pit shall fall into it; and whoso breaketh an hedge, a serpent shall bite him.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Whoso removeth stones shall be hurt therewith; and he that cleaveth wood shall be endangered thereby.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: If the iron be blunt, and he do not whet the edge, then must he put to more strength: but wisdom is profitable to direct.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Surely the serpent will bite without enchantment; and a babbler is no better.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The words of a wise man's mouth are gracious; but the lips of a fool will swallow up himself.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishness: and the end of his talk is mischievous madness.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A fool also is full of words: a man cannot tell what shall be; and what shall be after him, who can tell him?

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The labour of the foolish wearieth every one of them, because he knoweth not how to go to the city.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Woe to thee, O land, when thy king is a child, and thy princes eat in the morning!

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Blessed art thou, O land, when thy king is the son of nobles, and thy princes eat in due season, for strength, and not for drunkenness!

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: By much slothfulness the building decayeth; and through idleness of the hands the house droppeth through.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: A feast is made for laughter, and wine maketh merry: but money answereth all things.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Curse not the king, no not in thy thought; and curse not the rich in thy bedchamber: for a bird of the air shall carry the voice, and that which hath wings shall tell the matter.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Cast thy bread upon the waters: for thou shalt find it after many days.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Give a portion to seven, and also to eight; for thou knowest not what evil shall be upon the earth.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: If the clouds be full of rain, they empty themselves upon the earth: and if the tree fall toward the south, or toward the north, in the place where the tree falleth, there it shall be.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: He that observeth the wind shall not sow; and he that regardeth the clouds shall not reap.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: As thou knowest not what is the way of the spirit, nor how the bones do grow in the womb of her that is with child: even so thou knowest not the works of God who maketh all.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: In the morning sow thy seed, and in the evening withhold not thine hand: for thou knowest not whether shall prosper, either this or that, or whether they both shall be alike good.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Truly the light is sweet, and a pleasant thing it is for the eyes to behold the sun:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: But if a man live many years, and rejoice in them all; yet let him remember the days of darkness; for they shall be many. All that cometh is vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Rejoice, O young man, in thy youth; and let thy heart cheer thee in the days of thy youth, and walk in the ways of thine heart, and in the sight of thine eyes: but know thou, that for all these things God will bring thee into judgment.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Therefore remove sorrow from thy heart, and put away evil from thy flesh: for childhood and youth are vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Remember now thy Creator in the days of thy youth, while the evil days come not, nor the years draw nigh, when thou shalt say, I have no pleasure in them;

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: While the sun, or the light, or the moon, or the stars, be not darkened, nor the clouds return after the rain:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: In the day when the keepers of the house shall tremble, and the strong men shall bow themselves, and the grinders cease because they are few, and those that look out of the windows be darkened,

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And the doors shall be shut in the streets, when the sound of the grinding is low, and he shall rise up at the voice of the bird, and all the daughters of musick shall be brought low;

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Also when they shall be afraid of that which is high, and fears shall be in the way, and the almond tree shall flourish, and the grasshopper shall be a burden, and desire shall fail: because man goeth to his long home, and the mourners go about the streets:

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Or ever the silver cord be loosed, or the golden bowl be broken, or the pitcher be broken at the fountain, or the wheel broken at the cistern.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Then shall the dust return to the earth as it was: and the spirit shall return unto God who gave it.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Vanity of vanities, saith the preacher; all is vanity.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And moreover, because the preacher was wise, he still taught the people knowledge; yea, he gave good heed, and sought out, and set in order many proverbs.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The preacher sought to find out acceptable words: and that which was written was upright, even words of truth.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: The words of the wise are as goads, and as nails fastened by the masters of assemblies, which are given from one shepherd.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: And further, by these, my son, be admonished: of making many books there is no end; and much study is a weariness of the flesh.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: Let us hear the conclusion of the whole matter: Fear God, and keep his commandments: for this is the whole duty of man.

column8: Ecclesiastes or, The Preacher
column17: For God shall bring every work into judgment, with every secret thing, whether it be good, or whether it be evil.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: The song of songs, which is Solomon's.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth: for thy love is better than wine.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Because of the savour of thy good ointments thy name is as ointment poured forth, therefore do the virgins love thee.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Draw me, we will run after thee: the king hath brought me into his chambers: we will be glad and rejoice in thee, we will remember thy love more than wine: the upright love thee.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I am black, but comely, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, as the tents of Kedar, as the curtains of Solomon.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Look not upon me, because I am black, because the sun hath looked upon me: my mother's children were angry with me; they made me the keeper of the vineyards; but mine own vineyard have I not kept.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Tell me, O thou whom my soul loveth, where thou feedest, where thou makest thy flock to rest at noon: for why should I be as one that turneth aside by the flocks of thy companions?

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: If thou know not, O thou fairest among women, go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock, and feed thy kids beside the shepherds' tents.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I have compared thee, O my love, to a company of horses in Pharaoh's chariots.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thy cheeks are comely with rows of jewels, thy neck with chains of gold.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: We will make thee borders of gold with studs of silver.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: While the king sitteth at his table, my spikenard sendeth forth the smell thereof.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: A bundle of myrrh is my wellbeloved unto me; he shall lie all night betwixt my breasts.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: My beloved is unto me as a cluster of camphire in the vineyards of En-gedi.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; thou hast doves' eyes.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant: also our bed is green.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: The beams of our house are cedar, and our rafters of fir.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I am the rose of Sharon, and the lily of the valleys.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: As the lily among thorns, so is my love among the daughters.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: As the apple tree among the trees of the wood, so is my beloved among the sons. I sat down under his shadow with great delight, and his fruit was sweet to my taste.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: He brought me to the banqueting house, and his banner over me was love.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Stay me with flagons, comfort me with apples: for I am sick of love.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: His left hand is under my head, and his right hand doth embrace me.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes, and by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, till he please.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: The voice of my beloved! behold, he cometh leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon the hills.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: My beloved is like a roe or a young hart: behold, he standeth behind our wall, he looketh forth at the windows, shewing himself through the lattice.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: My beloved spake, and said unto me, Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: For, lo, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone;

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: The flowers appear on the earth; the time of the singing of birds is come, and the voice of the turtle is heard in our land;

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: The fig tree putteth forth her green figs, and the vines with the tender grape give a good smell. Arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: O my dove, that art in the clefts of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs, let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice; for sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Take us the foxes, the little foxes, that spoil the vines: for our vines have tender grapes.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: My beloved is mine, and I am his: he feedeth among the lilies.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Until the day break, and the shadows flee away, turn, my beloved, and be thou like a roe or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: By night on my bed I sought him whom my soul loveth: I sought him, but I found him not.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I will rise now, and go about the city in the streets, and in the broad ways I will seek him whom my soul loveth: I sought him, but I found him not.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: The watchmen that go about the city found me: to whom I said, Saw ye him whom my soul loveth?

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: It was but a little that I passed from them, but I found him whom my soul loveth: I held him, and would not let him go, until I had brought him into my mother's house, and into the chamber of her that conceived me.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes, and by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, till he please.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Who is this that cometh out of the wilderness like pillars of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and frankincense, with all powders of the merchant?

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Behold his bed, which is Solomon's; threescore valiant men are about it, of the valiant of Israel.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: They all hold swords, being expert in war: every man hath his sword upon his thigh because of fear in the night.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: King Solomon made himself a chariot of the wood of Lebanon.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: He made the pillars thereof of silver, the bottom thereof of gold, the covering of it of purple, the midst thereof being paved with love, for the daughters of Jerusalem.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Go forth, O ye daughters of Zion, and behold king Solomon with the crown wherewith his mother crowned him in the day of his espousals, and in the day of the gladness of his heart.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; thou hast doves' eyes within thy locks: thy hair is as a flock of goats, that appear from mount Gilead.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thy teeth are like a flock of sheep that are even shorn, which came up from the washing; whereof every one bear twins, and none is barren among them.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thy lips are like a thread of scarlet, and thy speech is comely: thy temples are like a piece of a pomegranate within thy locks.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thy neck is like the tower of David builded for an armoury, whereon there hang a thousand bucklers, all shields of mighty men.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thy two breasts are like two young roes that are twins, which feed among the lilies.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Until the day break, and the shadows flee away, I will get me to the mountain of myrrh, and to the hill of frankincense.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thou art all fair, my love; there is no spot in thee.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Come with me from Lebanon, my spouse, with me from Lebanon: look from the top of Amana, from the top of Shenir and Hermon, from the lions' dens, from the mountains of the leopards.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thou hast ravished my heart, my sister, my spouse; thou hast ravished my heart with one of thine eyes, with one chain of thy neck.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: How fair is thy love, my sister, my spouse! how much better is thy love than wine! and the smell of thine ointments than all spices!

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thy lips, O my spouse, drop as the honeycomb: honey and milk are under thy tongue; and the smell of thy garments is like the smell of Lebanon.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: A garden inclosed is my sister, my spouse; a spring shut up, a fountain sealed.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thy plants are an orchard of pomegranates, with pleasant fruits; camphire, with spikenard,

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Spikenard and saffron; calamus and cinnamon, with all trees of frankincense; myrrh and aloes, with all the chief spices:

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: A fountain of gardens, a well of living waters, and streams from Lebanon.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Awake, O north wind; and come, thou south; blow upon my garden, that the spices thereof may flow out. Let my beloved come into his garden, and eat his pleasant fruits.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I am come into my garden, my sister, my spouse: I have gathered my myrrh with my spice; I have eaten my honeycomb with my honey; I have drunk my wine with my milk: eat, O friends; drink, yea, drink abundantly, O beloved.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I sleep, but my heart waketh: it is the voice of my beloved that knocketh, saying, Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled: for my head is filled with dew, and my locks with the drops of the night.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I have put off my coat; how shall I put it on? I have washed my feet; how shall I defile them?

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: My beloved put in his hand by the hole of the door, and my bowels were moved for him.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I rose up to open to my beloved; and my hands dropped with myrrh, and my fingers with sweet smelling myrrh, upon the handles of the lock.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I opened to my beloved; but my beloved had withdrawn himself, and was gone: my soul failed when he spake: I sought him, but I could not find him; I called him, but he gave me no answer.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: The watchmen that went about the city found me, they smote me, they wounded me; the keepers of the walls took away my veil from me.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, if ye find my beloved, that ye tell him, that I am sick of love.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: What is thy beloved more than another beloved, O thou fairest among women? what is thy beloved more than another beloved, that thou dost so charge us?

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: My beloved is white and ruddy, the chiefest among ten thousand.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: His head is as the most fine gold, his locks are bushy, and black as a raven.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: His eyes are as the eyes of doves by the rivers of waters, washed with milk, and fitly set.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: His cheeks are as a bed of spices, as sweet flowers: his lips like lilies, dropping sweet smelling myrrh.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: His hands are as gold rings set with the beryl: his belly is as bright ivory overlaid with sapphires.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: His legs are as pillars of marble, set upon sockets of fine gold: his countenance is as Lebanon, excellent as the cedars.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: His mouth is most sweet: yea, he is altogether lovely. This is my beloved, and this is my friend, O daughters of Jerusalem.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Whither is thy beloved gone, O thou fairest among women? whither is thy beloved turned aside? that we may seek him with thee.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: My beloved is gone down into his garden, to the beds of spices, to feed in the gardens, and to gather lilies.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I am my beloved's, and my beloved is mine: he feedeth among the lilies.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thou art beautiful, O my love, as Tirzah, comely as Jerusalem, terrible as an army with banners.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Turn away thine eyes from me, for they have overcome me: thy hair is as a flock of goats that appear from Gilead.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thy teeth are as a flock of sheep which go up from the washing, whereof every one beareth twins, and there is not one barren among them.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: As a piece of a pomegranate are thy temples within thy locks.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: There are threescore queens, and fourscore concubines, and virgins without number.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: My dove, my undefiled is but one; she is the only one of her mother, she is the choice one of her that bare her. The daughters saw her, and blessed her; yea, the queens and the concubines, and they praised her.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Who is she that looketh forth as the morning, fair as the moon, clear as the sun, and terrible as an army with banners?

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I went down into the garden of nuts to see the fruits of the valley, and to see whether the vine flourished, and the pomegranates budded.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Or ever I was aware, my soul made me like the chariots of Amminadib.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Return, return, O Shulamite; return, return, that we may look upon thee. What will ye see in the Shulamite? As it were the company of two armies.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: How beautiful are thy feet with shoes, O prince's daughter! the joints of thy thighs are like jewels, the work of the hands of a cunning workman.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thy navel is like a round goblet, which wanteth not liquor: thy belly is like an heap of wheat set about with lilies.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thy two breasts are like two young roes that are twins.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thy neck is as a tower of ivory; thine eyes like the fishpools in Heshbon, by the gate of Bath-rabbim: thy nose is as the tower of Lebanon which looketh toward Damascus.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Thine head upon thee is like Carmel, and the hair of thine head like purple; the king is held in the galleries.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: How fair and how pleasant art thou, O love, for delights!

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: This thy stature is like to a palm tree, and thy breasts to clusters of grapes.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I said, I will go up to the palm tree, I will take hold of the boughs thereof: now also thy breasts shall be as clusters of the vine, and the smell of thy nose like apples;

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: And the roof of thy mouth like the best wine for my beloved, that goeth down sweetly, causing the lips of those that are asleep to speak.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I am my beloved's, and his desire is toward me.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Come, my beloved, let us go forth into the field; let us lodge in the villages.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Let us get up early to the vineyards; let us see if the vine flourish, whether the tender grape appear, and the pomegranates bud forth: there will I give thee my loves.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: The mandrakes give a smell, and at our gates are all manner of pleasant fruits, new and old, which I have laid up for thee, O my beloved.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: O that thou wert as my brother, that sucked the breasts of my mother! when I should find thee without, I would kiss thee; yea, I should not be despised.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I would lead thee, and bring thee into my mother's house, who would instruct me: I would cause thee to drink of spiced wine of the juice of my pomegranate.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: His left hand should be under my head, and his right hand should embrace me.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, until he please.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Who is this that cometh up from the wilderness, leaning upon her beloved? I raised thee up under the apple tree: there thy mother brought thee forth: there she brought thee forth that bare thee.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Set me as a seal upon thine heart, as a seal upon thine arm: for love is strong as death; jealousy is cruel as the grave: the coals thereof are coals of fire, which hath a most vehement flame.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: Many waters cannot quench love, neither can the floods drown it: if a man would give all the substance of his house for love, it would utterly be contemned.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: We have a little sister, and she hath no breasts: what shall we do for our sister in the day when she shall be spoken for?

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: If she be a wall, we will build upon her a palace of silver: and if she be a door, we will inclose her with boards of cedar.

column8: The Song of Solomon
column17: I am a wall, and my breasts like towers: then was I in his eyes as one that found favour.

column8: The Song of Solomon
